subsection.title: Dot Product of Vectors
subsection.p: Here, we define the dot product of vectors. First, for vectors in \mathbb{R}^2.

definition.p: Let \vec{u} = (u_1, u_2), \vec{v} = (v_1, v_2) \in \mathbb{R}^2 be vectors. Then, the dot product of \vec{u} and \vec{v}, denoted by \vec{u} \bullet \vec{v}, is the sum of the products of the corresponding components,

subsection.p: The name dot product comes from the fact that the multiplication is denoted by a dot. The dot product is also called the scalar product, because the product produces a scalar value. It is also called the inner product, for more complicated reasons.

subsection.title: Properties of the Dot Product

ol.li:
Associativity with scalar multiplication, for k \in \mathbb{R},
(k \vec{u}) \bullet \vec{v} = \vec{u} \bullet (k\vec{v}) = k(\vec{u} \bullet \vec{v})

subsection.proof:
Each of these properties basically follows from the definition of a dot product, and the corresponding properties for real numbers. Let \vec{u} = (u_1, u_2), \vec{v} = (v_1, v_2), \vec{w} = (w_1, w_2). Then,
\vec{u} \bullet \vec{v} \amp = u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2 \amp = v_1 u_1 + v_2 u_2 \amp = \vec{v} \bullet \vec{u}
\vec{u} \bullet (\vec{v} + \vec{w}) \amp = (u_1, u_2) \bullet (v_1 + w_1, v_2 + w_2) \amp = u_1(v_1 + w_1) + u_2(v_2 + w_2) \amp = u_1 v_1 + u_1 w_1 + u_2 v_2 + u_2 w_2 \amp = \brac{u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2} + \brac{u_1 w_1 + u_2 w_2} \amp = \vec{u} \bullet \vec{v} + \vec{u} \bullet \vec{w}
(k\vec{u}) \bullet \vec{v} \amp = (ku_1, ku_2) \bullet (v_1, v_2) \amp = ku_1 v_1 + ku_2 v_2
This expression is equal to,
= k\brac{u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2} = k (\vec{u} \bullet \vec{v})
This is also equal to,
= u_1 (k v_1) + u_2 (k v_2) = \vec{u} \bullet (k\vec{v})

subsection.title: Dot Product and Parallel-ness
subsection.p: Conversely, if \vec{u} \bullet \vec{v} = 0, then \abs{\vec{u}} \abs{\vec{v}} \cos{\theta} = 0. This implies that at least one of \abs{\vec{u}}, \abs{\vec{v}}, \cos{\theta} is 0. If \cos{\theta} = 0, then \theta = 90^{\circ}, and the vectors are perpendicular. If either of \abs{\vec{u}}, \abs{\vec{v}} are 0, then the corresponding vector is the zero vector, and recall that the zero vector is said to be perpendicular to all vectors. In summary,

corollary.title: Perpendicular if and only if zero dot product
corollary.p: Vectors \vec{u}, \vec{v} satisfy \vec{u} \bullet \vec{v} = 0 if and only if \vec{u} and \vec{v} are perpendicular.

definition.p: Let \vec{u} = (u_1, u_2, u_3), \vec{v} = (v_1, v_2, v_3) \in \mathbb{R}^3 be vectors. Then, the dot product of \vec{u} and \vec{v} is defined by,
definition.me: \boxed{\vec{u} \bullet \vec{v} = u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2 + u_3 v_3}

definition.p: Let \vec{u} = (u_1, \dots, u_n), \vec{v}_1 = (v_1, \dots, v_n) \in \mathbb{R}^n be vectors. Then, the dot product of \vec{u} and \vec{v} is defined by,
definition.me: \boxed{\vec{u} \bullet \vec{v} = u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2 \dots + u_n v_n = \sum_{k=1}^n u_k v_k}
